pullRequest.body:
This changes the way the ids are extracted for the `dupNamespace` linter.
Also we factor it out to a new file in anticipation of re-using that function in another linter.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [ac13e40421](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17631/commits/ac13e40421a77244781e5a0f60a1f763813d758c)

Import changes exceeding 2%

| %      | File |
| -      | -    |
| +300.00% | `Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.Lint` |

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.Lint | 1 | 4 | +3 (+300.00%) |
| Mathlib.Tactic | 2252 | 2255 | +3 (+0.13%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
There are 4869 files with changed transitive imports taking up over 199811 characters: this is too many to display!
You can run `scripts/import_trans_difference.sh all` locally to see the whole output.

</details>

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ getNamesFrom`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.
I think the import of `import Lean.DeclarationRange` causes the unpleaseant "large-import" label

Technically, I think that the `large-import` is a consequence of adding `Common` to `Lint`.  Still, in this case it is not such a big deal: the actual imports of `Lint` are not increased, as the extra imported file is simply to add one extra function.

The linter is now catching some hygienic names that have duplicated namespace since their paths have duplicated names!  This is a great test for the linter and maybe suggests that the linter should ignore hygienic names in its checks.

You mentioned in the other PR that `export`s are not working as intended: I remember that there was something special about them in the older version of the linter, but looking at the code, I cannot find anything about it.  I'll have to investigate further what is going on with `export`.

I pushed a small change to the linter and a fix for the `to_additive` test.  I'm not sure if this version will ignore those "internal" declarations that were triggering the linter, but we will see.

There is still the issue of `export`, but `alias` seems to behave as expected now.

The way in which I would fix the `export` issue checking, would be by extracting the information of the new declaration added in the environment extension `Lean.aliasExtension`, that `export` seems to update.  I won't have time to get around to this for several hours, so if someone else wants to give it a shot, feel free to do so!  It would be similar to how the `declRange` extension is accessed, but then it might be a little trickier to figure out what has been added, since the information is not recorded with the position where it was added.
Oh, those internal declarations still show up: maybe we simply have to exclude them explicitly.

pullRequest.title: chore(Tactic/Linter/Lint): improve dupNamespace

source.title: feat: lint declarations which contain a double underscore

nodes.body: I think the import of `import Lean.DeclarationRange` causes the unpleaseant "large-import" label

Technically, I think that the `large-import` is a consequence of adding `Common` to `Lint`.  Still, in this case it is not such a big deal: the actual imports of `Lint` are not increased, as the extra imported file is simply to add one extra function.

The linter is now catching some hygienic names that have duplicated namespace since their paths have duplicated names!  This is a great test for the linter and maybe suggests that the linter should ignore hygienic names in its checks.

You mentioned in the other PR that `export`s are not working as intended: I remember that there was something special about them in the older version of the linter, but looking at the code, I cannot find anything about it.  I'll have to investigate further what is going on with `export`.

I pushed a small change to the linter and a fix for the `to_additive` test.  I'm not sure if this version will ignore those "internal" declarations that were triggering the linter, but we will see.

There is still the issue of `export`, but `alias` seems to behave as expected now.

The way in which I would fix the `export` issue checking, would be by extracting the information of the new declaration added in the environment extension `Lean.aliasExtension`, that `export` seems to update.  I won't have time to get around to this for several hours, so if someone else wants to give it a shot, feel free to do so!  It would be similar to how the `declRange` extension is accessed, but then it might be a little trickier to figure out what has been added, since the information is not recorded with the position where it was added.
Oh, those internal declarations still show up: maybe we simply have to exclude them explicitly.
